citations.narrative:
A male patas monkey was acquired by this facility from a USDA-licensed breeder in another state. The animal was
accepted and was transported in commerce (across state lines) by this facility with no required Health Certificate
examination being conducted or documented prior to this transport. Upon arrival into this facility’s home state, the animal
was examined by this facility’s Attending Veterinarian prior to transfer to the facility site. Accepting a non-human primate
and transporting it in commerce without the required Health Certificate examination and documentation puts those
transporting the animal and the animals at the receiving facility at risk of exposure to communicable diseases.
The regulations state that no dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, broker, or department, agency, or
instrumentality of the United States or of any State or local government shall transport in commerce any dog, cat, or
nonhuman primate unless the dog, cat, or nonhuman primate is accompanied by a health certificate executed and issued
by a licensed veterinarian. Correct by 29Sep2023.

Two Flemish Giant rabbits were observed by the inspector to be resting in the only clean spaces in their enclosures. The
remaining areas in the enclosure contained excess amounts of feces and soiled straw. Not maintaining adequate
sanitation levels puts the rabbits at risk of skin scald and exposure to disease transmission through contact with feces and
vectors attracted to the feces (flies, rodents, and similar).
The regulations state that primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by
periodic cleaning.

The enclosure to which the vervet monkey was moved does not have an adequate barrier to prevent public interaction
with the monkey. Additional smaller-opening fencing has been purchased but is not in place during this inspection. Being
able to touch the hand and arms of the monkey and/or the public puts both the monkey and the public at risk for injury
and/or communicable disease transmission.
The regulations state that fixed public exhibits housing nonhuman primates, such as zoos, must have a barrier between
the primary enclosure and the public at any time the public is present, in order to restrict physical contact between the
public and the nonhuman primates.

Three avian enclosures (A - 2 macaws, B -12 macaws, C - 3 umbrella cockatoos) lack adequate provisions and/or shelter
to allow avoidance of precipitation, wind and/or sun for all birds in the enclosures. Not providing adequate shelter and/or
protection from precipitation, wind and sun puts the birds at risk of undue stress and illness due to the lack of the ability to
protect themselves from impactful weather elements.
The regulations state that primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that: they ensure that birds have
the option to remain dry and clean; that they provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental
conditions that may be detrimental to its health and well-being; that they provide sufficient shade to comfortably shelter all
birds housed in the primary enclosure at one time, including low ranking birds that are maintained in social groupings that
form dominance hierarchies.
Correct by 11October2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.78(a) 
   
Health certification and identification. 
A male patas monkey was acquired by this facility from a USDA-licensed breeder in another state. The animal was 
accepted and was transported in commerce (across state lines) by this facility with no required Health Certificate 
examination being conducted or documented prior to this transport. Upon arrival into this facility’s home state, the animal 
was examined by this facility’s Attending Veterinarian prior to transfer to the facility site. Accepting a non-human primate 
and transporting it in commerce without the required Health Certificate examination and documentation puts those 
transporting the animal and the animals at the receiving facility at risk of exposure to communicable diseases.  
 
The regulations state that no dealer, exhibitor, operator of an auction sale, broker, or department, agency, or 
instrumentality of the United States or of any State or local government shall transport in commerce any dog, cat, or 
nonhuman primate unless the dog, cat, or nonhuman primate is accompanied by a health certificate executed and issued 
by a licensed veterinarian. Correct by 29Sep2023. 
3.56(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
Two Flemish Giant rabbits were observed by the inspector to be resting in the only clean spaces in their enclosures. The 
remaining areas in the enclosure contained excess amounts of feces and soiled straw. Not maintaining adequate 
sanitation levels puts the rabbits at risk of skin scald and exposure to disease transmission through contact with feces and 
vectors attracted to the feces (flies, rodents, and similar).  
 
The regulations state that primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by 
periodic cleaning. 
3.78(e)  Repeat
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The enclosure to which the vervet monkey was moved does not have an adequate barrier to prevent public interaction 
with the monkey. Additional smaller-opening fencing has been purchased but is not in place during this inspection. Being 
able to touch the hand and arms of the monkey and/or the public puts both the monkey and the public at risk for injury

and/or communicable disease transmission.  
 
The regulations state that fixed public exhibits housing nonhuman primates, such as zoos, must have a barrier between 
the primary enclosure and the public at any time the public is present, in order to restrict physical contact between the 
public and the nonhuman primates. 
3.153(a) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three avian enclosures (A - 2 macaws, B -12 macaws, C - 3 umbrella cockatoos) lack adequate provisions and/or shelter 
to allow avoidance of precipitation, wind and/or sun for all birds in the enclosures. Not providing adequate shelter and/or 
protection from precipitation, wind and sun puts the birds at risk of undue stress and illness due to the lack of the ability to 
protect themselves from impactful weather elements.  
 
The regulations state that primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that: they ensure that birds have 
the option to remain dry and clean; that they provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental 
conditions that may be detrimental to its health and well-being; that they provide sufficient shade to comfortably shelter all 
birds housed in the primary enclosure at one time, including low ranking birds that are maintained in social groupings that 
form dominance hierarchies.  
Correct by 11October2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
